data.text: Water and irrigation
Although Pakistan is a dry country, some great rivers flow through our nation.
To ensure that crops get a steady supply of water, farmers have to irrigate their fields.
Irrigation
Canal irrigation involves digging water channels from rivers or lakes to agricultural fields.
Dams and barrages are constructed over rivers to divert water through canals to fields.
All large rivers of Pakistan have canals running off them.
Warsak, Mangla, Tarbela, Bolan, and Rawal are some of the famous dams of Pakistan.
Shaduf and Charsa are two ancient methods of irrigation.
A Shaduf consists of a long pole with a bucket suspended by a rope at one end and a weight at the other.
A Charsa consists of a bucket attached to a pulley. Animals are used to pull the water to the surface.
Persian wheel is another method of irrigation.
A Persian wheel consists of a number of buckets attached to a wheel. The wheel is rotated by an animal.
As the wheel rotates, the buckets dip into the water below and come up with water.
The water is tipped into a small channel connected to the fields.
Karez is an underground water tunnel used for irrigation.
The water from Karez comes to the surface and led to the fields and orchards.
The use of tube wells is a modern method of irrigation.
Water is pumped up from deep below the ground and used for irrigation.
Water for irrigation is obtained mainly from wells and canals.
